thread.title: Unicorn Startups In China Face Higher Hurdles For Next Jumps
thread.title_full: Unicorn Startups In China Face Higher Hurdles For Next Jumps

author: Rebecca Fannin
title: Unicorn Startups In China Face Higher Hurdles For Next Jumps
text: Unicorns or venture-backed companies with a valuation of more than $1 billion that have popped up everywhere and total 131 worldwide, may face strong headwinds in these shaky economic times. China, which has weighed in heavily claiming 18 companies with unicorn status -- up from 11 just a year ago – could be particularly unsteady. China’s economic slowdown and stock market volatility will likely impact the growth rate of these Chinese unicorns and other startups globally. Look for far fewer financings at stratospheric levels too as venture capitalists draw back and harvest their current set of portfolio companies for investment returns. Those VC firms that invested early in these startup stars before valuations soared in later financings will be the winners. VCs speaking at Silicon Dragon forums admit it’s challenging to gauge when to go ahead for fear of missing out on a champion or when to hold back due to risks. Silicon Dragon’s ranking of China’s top ten most valued Chinese startups (below) offers a snapshot today of these breakthrough leaders, ranging from fintech to hardware to social shopping and adtech. Notably, four of the ten most valuable startups in China are in e-commerce, pumped up by China’s advanced mobile commerce and payment platforms. Watch this space as the rankings and numbers are likely to change fast in the coming months. 1. Xiaomi Valuation : $46 billion Total funding : $1.45 billion VC backers: Digital Sky Technologies, Qiming Venture Partners, Qualcomm Ventures, Morningside Group, IDG Capital Partners Most recent round : $1.1 billion Series E, December 19, 2014 (with an additional undisclosed Series E - II by Ratan Tata, April 26, 2015) Founded in 2010, this fast-growing Chinese hardware company specializing in high-end smartphones with low price points, achieved an incredibly high $46 billion valuation in December 2014, up from $10 billion in January 2014. Facebook takes honors as the only VC-backed startup to have ever raised capital at a higher valuation-- in 2011 in an investment from Goldman Sachs that valued Facebook at $50 billion.Having surpassed Samsung in 2014 to become China’s top smartphone seller, capital is now being poured into increasing sales in key growth markets India, Southeast Asia and Brazil. Xiaomi is taking on the wearable market too with the Mi Band, competing with front-runners Fitbit and Apple.Known for its customer-centered innovation model, Xiaomi relies on crowdfunding to gauge appeal of ecosystem products, manufacturing those with high enough demand. 2. Didi Kuaidi Valuation : $15 billion Total funding : $3.4 billion VC backers : Matrix Partners China, Tiger Global Management, Softbank Corp., Alibaba Group, Tencent, China Investment Corp. Most recent round : Unspecified amount by China Investment Corp., July 2015. Didi Kuaidi, Uber’s biggest rival in China and the market’s dominant taxi-hailing app, is the result of a February 2015 merger of China’s Kuaidi Dache and Didi Dache. Only two months before the merger, Didi Dache closed $700 million in funding while Kuaidi Dache pulled in $600 million.Investment from sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corp. gives Didi Kuadi a backer with even deeper pockets than existing investors Alibaba and Tencent.The Hangzhou-based company, which handles more than 3 million rides a day, is gearing up with the recent addition of carpooling and personal chauffeur services. 3. Lufax Valuation : $10 billion Total funding : $485 million VC backers include : Ping An Ventures, CDH Investments, China international Capital Corporation, Morgan Stanley Most recent round : $485 million private equity investment, April 18, 2015This Shanghai-based fintech company, launched in March 2012, has emerged as one of the largest peer-to-peer lenders in China. It runs two online lending platforms and 100 storefronts across 80 cities that provide financing and lending services for small and medium enterprises as well as individuals. Lufax has arranged more than 200,000 peer-to-peer loans worth some $2.5 billion. 4. DJI Innovations Valuation : $10 billion Total funding : $75 million VC backers : Accel Partners, Sequoia Capital Most recent round : $75 million Series B, May 6, 2015 Founded in 2006, made-in-China drone maker DJI has gained recognition as a Chinese startup helping to lead innovation in a cutting-edge tech market. DJI’s critically acclaimed quad copters run the gamut from high-trade toys to professional-grade drones for pilots and filmmakers.Based in Shenzhen, global operations for this leading drone maker span North America, Europe and Asia with customers in 100-plus countries and revenues expected to exceed $1 billion 2015. 5. Meituan Valuation : $7 billion Total funding : $1.06 billion VC backers : Sequoia Capital, General Atlantic, Alibaba Group Most recent round : $700 million Series D, December 22, 2014The “Groupon of China,” Meituan, China’s largest group buying site, claims 20 million daily mobile users in more than 1000 cities.Meituan came online in March 2010 with $12 million in initial funding from Sequoia Capital. This latest round of funding could be the company’s last before seeking an IPO, potentially in the U.S. 6. Dianping Valuation : $4.05 billion Total funding : $1.41 billion VC backers : Qiming Venture Partners, Lightspeed China Partners, Sequoia Capital, Trustbridge Partners, Tencent, Wanda Group, Fosun Kinzon Capital, Xiaomi Most recent round : $850 million Series E, April 5, 2015Dianping, often described as a mixture of Yelp and Groupon, offers restaurant reviews and reservation services, group buying as well as more recently, massages and hotel bookings.Viewed as a competitor with #5 Chinese Unicorn Meituan, Dianping’s business model focuses on tier one and two cities, generating revenue through paid listings and discounts. Notably, Tencent’s 2014 investment got Meituan’s services integrated with instant messaging app WeChat, driving the business to a new level. 7. VANCL Valuation : $3 billion Total funding : $430 million VC backers: Ceyuan Ventures, Qiming Venture Partners, Temasek Holdings, SAIF Partners, IDG Capital Partners, Most recent round : $100 million Series G, February 10, 2014Online-only apparel retailer and e-tailor VANCL features its own-brand clothing. Founded in 2007 and headquartered in Beijing, the platform offers men’s and women’s fashions, shoes, jeans, and other lifestyle goods. 8. Trendy Group International Valuation : $2 billion Total funding : $200 million VC backer : L Capital Partners Most recent round : $200M private equity investment, February 13, 2012 Founded 1999 in Guangzhou, Trendy Group International began as a jewelry wholesaler and morphed into a casual-wear company. Today, in addition to directly owning hundreds of stores, Trendy Group has hundreds of franchises for four brands, including its largest, Ochirly, and sells products online and through its retail stores. 9. Lakala Valuation : $1.6 billion Total funding : $242 million VC backers : Fortune Venture Investment Group, China Renaissance Capital Investment Most recent round : $242 million, June 23, 2015 Founded in 2005, this consumer financial service provides offline payments services and owns 30,000-plus kiosks in convenience stores and supermarkets in 30 cities across China. From Beijing, Lakala manages 25 branch offices across China and claims to have processed more than 2 trillion RMB worth of payment transactions.Recognized as an innovator in China’s e-payment sector, Lakala offers software solutions for electronic payments as well as utility billing and digital loyalty programs.Whether Lakala’s devices become outdated due to new mobile payments habits by China’s consumers remains to be seen. 10. Koudai Gouwu Valuation : $1.4 billion Total funding : $362 million VC backers : New Enterprise Associates, Tiger Global Management, Tencent, Chengwei Capital Most recent round : $350 million, October 23, 2014 Notably, in Koudai’s most recent round, Tencent contributed $145 million, for a 10 percent stake in the startup that offers intelligent shopping software “Koudai Shopping,” focused on mobile e-commerce.Uers can browse and make purchases on the site from within Tencent’s popular WeChat messaging app, and vendors can market their own shops through Koudai’s WeChat channels.Leveraging its search technology, Koudai aims to become a leading shopping traffic gateway on the mobile Internet. The company, founded in 2010 and based in Beijing, is viewed as a competitor to Alibaba on mobile. Other Chinese unicorns that did not make the Top 10 cut include the following:Mobile software: Apus Group -This youngest member of the billion-dollar club, mobile software maker Apus surpassed 200 million users worldwide since a July 2014 launch in Beijing Fintech: China Rapid Finance - A leader in mobile and online lending with one of China’s largest platforms for online consumer lending marketplaces Social: Mogujie - A social shopping service specializing in women’s fashion formed by two former employees of Alibaba’s Taobao marketplace Adtech: Panshi – An adtech player from Hangzhou focusing on serving small and medium-sized enterprises eCommerce: Tujia - A popular vacation rental service often compared with AirBNB that is expanding into Asian destinations popular with Chinese tourists Fanli - An online discount provider claiming to be the largest e-commerce store pinpointing rebate-based loyalty shopping Beibei – A maternal and infant-supplies platform based in Hangzhou that offers discount clothing, shoes and toys iwjw.com – A mobile Internet-based real estate agency firm that helps young people in tier 1 cities find apartments to buy or rent (*The rankings were drawn from CBI Insights and news reports with additional research by Silicon Dragon contributor Ying-Ying Lu.)
